user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketOpen:
```c
int32 OS_SocketOpen(osal_id_t *sock_id, OS_SocketDomain_t Domain, OS_SocketType_t Type)
{
    OS_object_token_t            token;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    int32                        return_code;

    /* Check for NULL pointers */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(sock_id);

    /* Note - the common ObjectIdAllocate routine will lock the object type and leave it locked. */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, NULL, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, token);

        /* Save all the data to our own internal table */
        memset(stream, 0, sizeof(OS_stream_internal_record_t));
        stream->socket_domain = Domain;
        stream->socket_type   = Type;

        /* Now call the OS-specific implementation.  This reads info from the table. */
        return_code = OS_SocketOpen_Impl(&token);

        /* Check result, finalize record, and unlock global table. */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew(return_code, &token, sock_id);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
memset(stream, 0, sizeof(OS_stream_internal_record_t));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The pointer 'stream' is intended to be modified (it is cleared/initialized with memset and later assigned to), so it must not be a pointer-to-const. MISRA 8.13 recommends using pointers-to-const when possible, but here modification is required, so using a non-const OS_stream_internal_record_t * is appropriate.
